title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.44 | 18-01-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananj Nishalakaya Chakshurun Meelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: Gross military science is dependent on material weapons but finer than that is the art of throwing arrows saturated with Vedic hymns which act more effectively than gross material weapons like machine guns or atom bombs.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam about Dhanurveda, the Vedic military science, and how it involves controlling weapons with Vedic hymns, a science lost in modern times.

segments.key_quote: He could pierce his target with his arrow by only hearing the sound without seeing the object.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Maharaj Dasaratha and his mastery of Shabda Vedi, the art of hitting a target by sound, and how he accidentally killed a Brahmachari named Shravan Kumar, leading to negative consequences.

segments.key_quote: So I have come to give you water. Then they were ecstatic. They were extremely aggrieved because only his son, they were dependent on him.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the story of Dasharatha, explaining how the Brahmachari's parents cursed him, leading to his grief and death due to Rama's exile, but ultimately, Dasharatha was blessed to have the Supreme Lord as his son.

segments.key_quote: The Vedas ultimate goal is to know or understand Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the Upavedas, including Dhanurveda, Ayurveda, Sthapatyaveda, and Gandharvaveda, emphasizing that the ultimate goal of the Vedas is to understand Krishna and our relationship with Him.

segments.key_quote: They are not carried away by those skills.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of the Pandavas to illustrate how even with worldly achievements, pure devotees remain focused on Krishna consciousness and detachment, ultimately renouncing everything to return to the Lord.
